story.name: a16ebdfd-7e51-4899-adf7-aca3cdc3d1b5
story.title: Vietnam jails former deputy labour minister for economic mismanagement
story.summary: VIETNAM-SECURITY/TRIALS:Vietnam jails former deputy labour minister for economic mismanagement

xmlText.p: Vietnam jails former deputy labour minister for economic mismanagement
HANOI, Sept 25 (Reuters) - A court in Vietnam on Wednesday sentenced a former deputy labour minister to six years in prison after finding him guilty of economic mismanagement, state media reported.

Le Bach Hong, who had been deputy minister of labour, invalids and social affairs, and a former head of Vietnam Social Security, was also ordered by the People's Court of Hanoi to pay a cash fine of 150 billion dong ($6.47 million), reported An Ninh Thu Do newspaper, which is run by the Hanoi Police Department.
Reuters was unable to reach Hong's lawyer for comments.
The trial comes amid a corruption crackdown in the Southeast Asian country that has seen several senior government officials and executives of state-owned enterprises arrested and jailed.
The report said Hong and others illegally lent state money to a local financial company that went bankrupt in 2018, causing losses of nearly 1.7 trillion dong ($73.3 million) to the state budget.

The court also sentenced five other former officials of Vietnam Social Security to between two and 14 years in prison for the same charges, according to the report. ($1 = 23,200 dong) (Reporting by Khanh Vu; Editing by Toby Chopra)
